value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">10</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">tunes to the words that the writers wrote.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">It is the printing press 
            <choice>
              <sic>th t</sic>
              <corr>that</corr>
            </choice> disturbs this company.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">It is the printing press that makes the writer a 
            <choice>
              <sic>nany</sic>
              <corr>many</corr>
            </choice> headed</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">many limbed. a mongrel with so many different 
            <choice>
              <sic>pearants</sic>
              <corr>parents</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">that it requires a 
            <choice>
              <sic>hole</sic>
              <corr>whole</corr>
            </choice> army of learned men, and a perpetual</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">provision of fine tasters to keep any order or distinction</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>etween</sic>
              <corr>between</corr>
            </choice> the different members. The presses of <rs type="place" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#pla-lond" key="London">London</rs>, <rs type="place" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#pla-oxfo" key="Oxford"/></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="place" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#pla-camb" key="Cambridge">
            <choice>
              <sic>Ca,bridge</sic>
              <corr>Cambridge</corr>
            </choice></rs>, sucking in copy, and casting out legible books</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">that 
            <choice>
              <sic>nany one</sic>
              <corr>any one</corr>
            </choice> could read was not a nice 
            <choice>
              <sic>fedder</sic>
              <corr>[feeder?]</corr>
            </choice>. Anything</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">that could be written could be printed. What Any morality,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">any record, whatever men wished 
            <choice>
              <sic>recored</sic>
              <corr>recorded</corr>
            </choice>, it would deliver</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">as a book. Unlike the 
            <choice>
              <sic>pa nter</sic>
              <corr>painter</corr>
            </choice> or the musician the writer</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">after the birth of the printing press is exposed to</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">innumerable 
            <choice>
              <sic>inappropirate</sic>
              <corr>inappropriate</corr>
            </choice> and 
            <choice>
              <sic>irelveant</sic>
              <corr>irrelevant</corr>
            </choice> 
            <choice>
              <sic>s licitaions</sic>
              <corr>solcitations</corr>
            </choice>.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Why not write the 
            <choice>
              <sic>hist</sic>
              <corr>history</corr>
            </choice> of your parish? Or the life of a</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Roman emperor? Why not take part in the 
            <choice>
              <sic>governement</sic>
              <corr>government</corr>
            </choice> of your</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">country? Why not advise the soul of its 
            <choice>
              <sic>erils</sic>
              <corr>perils</corr>
            </choice>? Why not become</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>pampheleteer</sic>
              <corr>pamphleteer</corr>
            </choice> 
            <choice>
              <sic>histroain</sic>
              <corr>historian</corr>
            </choice> moralist, or playwright? The Press is</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">read to accept anything. And as the 
            <choice>
              <sic>oublic</sic>
              <corr>public</corr>
            </choice> becomes less</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>serivile</sic>
              <corr>servile</corr>
            </choice>, less martial less concerned to keep out the cold</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and fight the enemy, as glass is fitted into windows</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and pillows replace logs, the public adds its own invitation</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">to the writer. It is an inquisitive 
            <choice>
              <sic>acti e</sic>
              <corr>active</corr>
            </choice> minded public;</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">it soon dissipates and takes hold of <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-anon" key="Anon">Anon</rs>. It makes him</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">into an innumerable 
            <choice>
              <sic>comany</sic>
              <corr>company</corr>
            </choice> of familiar 
            <choice>
              <sic>sprits</sic>
              <corr>spirits</corr>
            </choice>, one</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>pr aching</sic>
              <corr>preaching</corr>
            </choice> another delighting, 
            <choice>
              <sic>anotherinstructing</sic>
              <corr>another instructing</corr>
            </choice>. Only a few</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">still persist into making words into works of art.</l>
